node.text:
Welcome to the eighth installment of #TheCurrent — your inside look into what’s happening at Surfrider.

In this episode, Surfrider CEO, Dr. Chad Nelsen, speaks with Water Quality Manager, Mara Dias, to discuss the Surfrider Foundation's efforts across our network to protect clean water so that it's safe to surf, swim and play in the water at the beach.

You can join us in our efforts to #StopSewagePollution and to protect clean water by sending an email to your representatives in Congress — asking them to invest in repairing and upgrading America's failing wastewater infrastructure. Click the link in our bio to take action.

#StopSewagePollution
#CleanWaterHealthyBeaches

node.title: The Current: Episode 008 — Protecting Clean Water

node.text:
“Change is not easy. Change is not fast. But there are a lot of people on Capitol Hill—who we met and we had the chance to talk to—who we know are on our side when it comes to trying to protect the environment, protecting clean water, stopping plastic pollution, fighting climate change.”
- Alex Vai (@mildlyinterestingpuffin)

At this year’s Coastal Recreation Hill Day, hundreds of Surfrider activists, recreation industry leaders, partners, and ambassadors had the opportunity to meet with our nation’s federal leaders and urge them to protect our coasts and ocean.

Now it is your turn. Together, we can slow the effects of climate change, stop the flow of plastics into our environment, and keep our waters clean and healthy. You have the power to affect change, both locally and nationally. Click the link in our bio to join us and be part of the positive change that our planet so desperately needs.

#SurfriderHillDay
#RisingSeas

📽: @lieberfilms

Featuring: @southsoundsurfrider @surfrider_washington @surfriderma @surfrideruh @surfriderclubnetwork @surfridersf @surfriderla @surfridersandiego @surfridersoc @hsbsurfrider @reef @dragonalliance @olympicpeninsulasurfrider

node.text:
Welcome to the seventh installment of #TheCurrent — your inside look into what’s happening at Surfrider.

In this episode, Surfrider CEO, Dr. Chad Nelsen, speaks with Staff Scientist, Katie Day, who is organizing Coastal Recreation Hill Day. This year we are bringing together over 160 people—Surfrider chapters, clubs, recreation industry leaders and partners— to meet virtually with our nation’s federal leaders to urge them to protect our coasts and ocean.

#SurfriderHillDay #RisingSeas

node.title: The Current: Episode 007 — Coastal Recreation Hill Day 2021

node.text:
This #BlackHistoryMonth we are celebrating our activists, friends, colleagues and like-minded organizations from within the Surfrider network. Throughout the month we will recognize those who inspire us and celebrate the achievements they've made to help protect our ocean, waves and beaches, while supporting beach access for all.

This short film, titled “On The Side Of Right,” features waterwoman, surfer, and founder of @surfearnegra, GiGi Lucas, and the historical efforts to desegregate the beaches of St. Augustine, Florida during the civil rights movement—accompanied by a moving and iconic speech from Martin Luther King Jr.

To learn more and help continue to #DiversifyTheLineup, please click the link in our bio or visit surfearnegra.com

🎥: @thewuss @theseea
🏄‍♀️: @living_inthelight

node.text:
This has been a challenging year to say the least. But thanks to the tireless efforts of our grassroots network of volunteers, alongside our expert staff, we achieved over 62 coastal victories to protect our ocean, waves and beaches.

We extend a heartfelt thank you to all of our chapters, clubs, supporters and partners who persevered through all the challenges that this year presented and still contributed to this great success.

node.text:
Welcome to the sixth installment of #TheCurrent — your inside look into what’s happening at Surfrider.

In this episode, Surfrider CEO, Dr. Chad Nelsen, speaks with Environmental Director, Pete Stauffer, about Surfrider’s plan to protect our coasts under the new Biden Presidential Administration.

node.title: The Current: Episode 006 — The Next 4 Years

node.text:
In honor of our #SmallActs4CleanShores campaign with @lovebeautyandplanet, we asked our friend, intersectional environmental activist and eco-communicator, @greengirlleah, to dive a bit deeper into why beach cleanups and reducing sources of pollution are important factors in addressing environmental injustice in our communities.

Join us by tuning in to our discussion with Leah on Tuesday, 10/27, as we set out to protect our shorelines and help influence change from the grassroots level. Click the link in our bio to learn more and get involved!

node.text:
Since 2005, we have achieved hundreds of victories to stop the flow of plastics into our environment, but these victories do not come easy. So how exactly do these plastic reduction policies, laws and bills get passed and implemented?

Join Surfrider ambassador and founder of @plasticfreefridays, @meg_haywoodsullivan, as she sits down to chat (and surf) with Surfrider staff and activists to learn how we pass important plastic reduction legislation.

Click the link in our bio to learn more about our plastic pollution campaigns and victories.

🎥: @lieberfilms

node.text:
Welcome to the fifth installment of #TheCurrent — your inside look into what’s happening at Surfrider.
〰️〰️〰️
In this episode, Surfrider CEO, Chad Nelsen, speaks with Jennie Romer, our Plastic Pollution Legal Associate, about how COVID-19 is affecting the pollution at our beaches, the safety of reusables bags and containers, Surfrider's current plastic policy work and how our beach cleanup data is helping to drive plastic policy nationwide.

node.title: The Current: Episode 005 — COVID-19 and Plastic Pollution

node.text:
As a part of #PlasticFreeJuly, we chat with Miho Ligare, our Plastic Pollution Policy Coordinator. Miho provides some background on Surfrider, some new policies that we are advocating for, and ways that you can reduce your single-use plastic footprint at home!

In case you missed any of our partners’ helpful #plasticfree tips this month, check out @dominiquedrakeford, @stasherbag, and @unitedbyblue's IGTV channels.

node.title: Take Action to Tackle Plastic Pollution

node.text:
How can you make your life more #OceanFriendly and be mindful of your plastic waste?

Think about using alternative products made of stainless steel, glass, wood, or other natural fibers like cotton, jute, wool, and hemp—instead of plastic.

Swap out single-use items with healthy and durable reusables. Swapping out plastics doesn't have to be expensive! For example, you can reuse glass jars or buy things at the thrift store.

When buying new things, ask yourself before you add it to your cart—“Do I really need this?” and “Is there a better alternative?”

Learn how you can make simple changes and reduce your plastic footprint as part of the #BetterBeachAlliance at surfrider.org (link in bio)

#BetterBeachAlliance
#CleanWaterHealthyBeaches

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Surfrider Foundation on August 06, 2021. May be an image of outdoors.

node.text:
Lawsuit Filed to Protect the Gulf of Mexico from Seismic Testing🐬

The Surfrider Foundation, along with a strong coalition of environmental groups, has filed a lawsuit to challenge rulemaking that would allow around-the-clock seismic airgun testing.This process—used to search for oil and gas deposits deep beneath the ocean floor—is extremely harmful and threatens marine life, including dolphins and whales that depend on their hearing for basic life functions like communication, navigation, and breeding.

“The level of damage to the marine mammals of the Gulf that NMFS is authorizing is immense and unacceptable” according to Cynthia Sarthou, Executive Director of Healthy Gulf. Click the link in our bio to learn more about the lawsuit.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by Surfrider Foundation on August 05, 2021 tagging @surfriderrincon. May be an image of sky, ocean, palm trees and nature.

node.text:
Puerto Rico's Tres Palmas Marine Reserve is Threatened by New Development ❌🏗

The Surfrider Foundation, led by our Rincon Chapter (@surfriderrincon), is calling upon federal agencies to protect threatened coral reefs and a world class surf break from nearby construction. A new residential housing structure has Surfrider and local community members particularly outraged and concerned.

Click the link in our bio to learn more!

node.text:
VICTORY #47: Hawaiʻi passes precedent-setting legislation to disclose the threats of climate change in coastal real estate transactions

Hawaiʻi just became the first state in the U.S. to pass a law requiring sea level rise disclosures in real estate transactions. While most states, including Hawaiʻi, have laws that require sellers to disclose hazards like repetitive flooding, fires, and tsunami danger, currently no state law requires a seller to disclose ‘sea level rise’ concerns.

Hawaiʻi’s new legislation is precedent-setting not only because it is the first law of its kind, but the legislation strikes an important balance of protecting both people's rights and coastal resources. Surfrider firmly believes that every potential homeowner has the inalienable right to know if a home is potentially in harm’s way and this is especially true as sea level rise and climate change impacts exponentially grow.

Click the link in our bio to learn more about this huge victory for our Hawaiʻi Chapters and for our communities as we deal with increasing threats due to climate change.

node.text:
It’s that time of year again...

Our 7th annual Creators & Innovators Upcycle Contest is here! We’ve partnered up with our friends at @visslasurf and @theecologycenter to challenge you, the wave conscious, to take something that might be considered waste and create something that can be used in the ocean.

Learn how to enter the Creators & Innovators Upcycle Contest and download a DIY hand plane template at vissla.com/creatorscontest. (link in bio)

🎥 @brianelliott
#creatorscontest

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by Surfrider Foundation on July 29, 2021 tagging @surfridercoastalbend. May be an image of 1 person.

node.text:
"It’s really the empowerment that I’ve experienced and the people I’ve gotten to work with in Surfrider that have made it special. It’s really inspiring to see everyone give their time and work together as a team to help protect the world’s beaches and ocean. And I can’t begin to count all the friendships I’ve made through Surfrider...we’re truly grassroots because we’re in the water and on the beaches. We see the hazards that plastic pollution and industry are creating for dolphins, sea turtles and other creatures, and we know how to stand up and fight for them."

-Neil McQueen is the Vice Chair of the Texas Coastal Bend Chapter (@surfridercoastalbend) and has led their #SkipThePlastic project since 2010—keeping Texas beaches and waterways free of #PlasticPollution.

Click the link in our bio to learn more about Neil & his amazing work in our latest #ActivistSpotlight!

node.text:
What is Surfrider doing to clean up our beaches?

Local Surfrider chapters have engaged over 120,000 volunteers in over 3,000 beach cleanups to remove over 850,000 pounds of trash from our beaches since 2015 alone.

We track data on the quantity, weight, amount, and types of litter collected at our beach cleanups and then use that data to pass vital laws and policies to eliminate plastic pollution at the source. Our beach cleanups save communities money and valuable resources and they are also an opportunity to engage new volunteers!

Learn how you can participate in a beach cleanup and become part of the #BetterBeachAlliance at surfrider.org (link in bio)

#CleanWaterHealthyBeaches

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by Surfrider Foundation on July 23, 2021 tagging @surfrideroregon, @surfridernewportor, @surfriderportland, and @coosbaysurfrider. May be an image of ocean, sky and text that says 'VICTORY 48'.

node.text:
VICTORY #48: Historic Climate Change Bill Passed in Oregon

On July 19, 2021 Oregon Governor Kate Brown signed HB 3114, a bill that makes strategic climate investments in Oregon's ocean. Surfrider Chapters in Oregon have been working since the inception of the Nearshore Task Force in 2010 to create a pathway for funding critical ocean science and adaptation issues.

Part of that effort, was the founding of Oregon's Ocean Science Trust, which was woefully never invested in by the state. HB 3114 marks the first investment of the State of Oregon in the Trust, providing nearly $2 million to strategically take climate action by supporting the science, adaptation, and mitigation of climate change impacts on Oregon's coast and ocean.

Thank you to ALL of our Oregon chapters who worked tirelessly to pass this critical legislation, as well as another bill which will protect Oregon’s seafloor and beaches! Click the link in our bio to learn more.

node.text:
The ocean connects us all. And with the eyes of the world about to witness surfing for the first time in Tokyo, keeping our precious ocean playground clean and healthy is more urgent than ever before. 🌊

We must come together as a global society to address these pressing environmental issues. By joining the Surfrider Foundation, you can help preserve and protect our ocean across the globe. (link in bio)

node.text:
How do our beaches get so trashed? Where does all of this trash come from?

The majority of the plastic in our ocean and on our beaches is from land-based sources—much of which comes from our everyday lives. Just take a look at the top 10 items commonly found at Surfrider beach cleanups.

Plastic bottles, straws, and food wrappers consistently make the list. However, not all pollution comes from littering. Even the trash you properly dispose of can end up in the environment. Plastic is very lightweight and can be easily blown away by the wind and can end up in our waterways and in our ocean.

Learn how you can participate in a beach cleanup and become part of the #BetterBeachAlliance at surfrider.org (link in bio)

#BetterBeachAlliance
#CleanWaterHealthyBeaches
